name: Stöng Viking Ruins Shelter
subtitle: First Icelandic heritage site with sustainability focus - 1957 shelter preserved

executive_summary.headline: Heritage preservation meets circular economy: 1957 timber shelter transformed with untreated larch and polycarbonate
key_achievements: First heritage site in Iceland designed with sustainability focus
1957 timber load-bearing structure retained and reinforced
Translucent polycarbonate roof for natural light
Mies van der Rohe Award 2026 nomination
executive_summary.why_tier2: Heritage preservation project with sustainability integration rather than explicit circular metrics. No LCA documentation. Strong architectural significance but limited quantified circularity data.

materials.description: 1957 timber load-bearing frame retained and reinforced
Translucent corrugated polycarbonate roof (Brett Martin) - allows natural light and airflow
Steel connectors and reinforcement to strengthen existing frame

co2_reduction.note: Estimated savings from structure reuse vs new construction

programs: Landsáætlun um uppbyggingu innviða til verndar náttúru og menningarsögulegum minjum

key_insights: Heritage preservation and material reuse can be combined
1957 shelter treated as 'artifact worth conserving in its own right'
Untreated larch viable in Icelandic climate
challenges: Protecting fragile archaeological remains while improving accessibility
Balancing modern intervention with heritage preservation

narrative.driver: Minjastofnun needed to protect 11th-century Viking ruins while improving access. Decided to preserve 1957 shelter rather than build new.
narrative.approach: Design competition winner treats 1957 shelter as 'artifact worth conserving'. Structure retained with untreated larch cladding and translucent polycarbonate roof.
narrative.significance: First heritage site in Iceland with sustainability focus. Protects both ancient ruins AND 1957 protective structure.
narrative.legacy: Model for heritage-circular integration. Dezeen longlist and Mies nomination validate approach.
